_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

The impermanent as conducive to extingui: The mendicant sees that the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are impermanent.
They see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also impermanent.
They see that the ear, sounds, ear consciousness, and ear contact are impermanent.
They see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by ear contact is also impermanent.
They see that the nose, smells, nose consciousness, and nose contact are impermanent.
They see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by nose contact is also impermanent.
They see that the tongue, tastes, tongue consciousness, and tongue contact are impermanent.
They see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by tongue contact is also impermanent.
They see that the body, touches, body consciousness, and body contact are impermanent.
They see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by body contact is also impermanent.
They see that the mind, thoughts, mind-consciousness, and mind contact are impermanent.
They see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also impermanent.
